captions.text: [ENGINE REVVING]
Good evening, everyone.

A few weeks ago I bought
a Ferrari.

Now why buy a Ferrari when
you've, quite publicly, stated

that you don't like
the company?

Well, because I like
the cars and I miss
not driving the cars.

But really this is
about value.

You see, 599 prices in the UK
have dipped sharply in the

past six months, and
I just thought it
looked like a good punt.

I mean, I know a car like this
is only about 15,000 pounds

more than the best
575 Maranello.

Now don't get me wrong, the 575
is a lovely old thing, but

the 599 is on a completely
different planet.

This is a fully fledged
supercar.

It has a 620-horsepower
[INAUDIBLE]

V12 with 448-foot pounds
of torque.
And it weighs 1750 kilograms.

The front brakes are 398
millimeter carbon ceramics.

And the rear tires are
305 section Pirellis.

It's also a GT car that will hit
100 miles an hour in seven

and a half seconds, do over
200 miles an hour, and--
to me--

looks the absolute business
in grigio silverstone.

It also uses fuel like nothing
I've ever owned.

I think there's a hole
in the fuel tank.
[ENGINE REVVING]

But what's it like to actually
drive this 599?

Pretty spectacular actually,
I have to say.

I'm a lucky swine in that I get
to drive lots of nice cars

on a daily basis, but this
thing-- every time I get into
it I think, wow.
I really do think, wow.

But I also think at full-noise,
in second gear,

when it's right lit, I think
to myself, it's got 620

horsepower and yet the car
that's just replaced it and

made this the old Ferrari
has got another-- what?
120 horsepower?

You do think to yourself, what
does that mean on the road?
How can you possibly use it?

Because I can't use 8/10 of the
performance of this car
most of the time.

Anyhow, I am a journalist, and
I have to state on the record

that you probably never can
have too much power when

you're in a supercar because
that's what they're all about.

And this is a supercar and I
quite like owning supercars.

I wouldn't say it's an easy car
to drive slowly either.

The old flappy paddle
gearbox is not to my
liking, I have to say.

Although this one isn't annoying
me as much as I
thought it might.

At low speed you have to sort of
just manage the throttle a

bit and watch out for the
odd creep and junctions.
It's not as you want it.

I'd love to have bought a car
with a stick, but in the UK,

apparently, none
were delivered.

And that meant going down the
route of buying one maybe in

Germany and shipping
it over here.

And I just got a bit scared and
thought, I won't be able
to sell it one day.
So I'm with paddles.

Once you're up and running, they
are fairly impressive and
the shift is fast.

And actually, you do get into
a groove, just having your
hands on the wheel.
[INAUDIBLE].

But there are maybe four or five
important components of
driving a car.

And not having three pedals and
a gear shift to wrestle

with, I feel I'm being denied
that percentage of the driving
experience.

Maybe I'm an old bastard, but
I feel it's quite important
and I miss it.
Rides pretty good.

I have to say I'd like to
have a soft [INAUDIBLE]

with the fast gear change, and
you can't separate that.
You had to have a [INAUDIBLE]

or 458 for them to
start doing that.

Might have a button under there
to be able to override
the function.

But other than that, my biggest
problem here is how am

I going to avoid doing too many
miles in it and making it

worth about 20 pence at the
end of my ownership.

That's a pretty good problem
to have, though, isn't it?

And, of course, when you switch
all the stuff off, you
can do this.
It's just lunacy.

So I'll drive it a bit quicker
now, and I'll try and tell you

what it's like to drive this
car quite quickly.

Second gear, almost can't use
it in the UK fully open

because it's got so
much [INAUDIBLE].

I've got shift lights on the
steering wheel, which are

quite helpful, because you can't
look down at the rev
counter when you're on.

Big car but the steering is
accurate so I can get it to
where I want it to be.
Listen to that noise.
Oh, yes.
It's very neutral.
And it's strange.

Even though your head tells
you this is a front-engine

car, it doesn't feel that way,
because it's got so much

traction when you just
[INAUDIBLE].

If you smash the throttle open
yeah, it's a problem.
It'll just spool up.

But if you feed it in it's got
loads of traction and feels
really well-balanced.

It's a physically big car
for the roads that
I drive it on certainly.

It's much bigger than
I expected it to be.
It feels kind of [INAUDIBLE]
wide.

The 512 is a smaller car, and I
think that's a really clever
development.

The weight, over 1700 kilograms,
you can't feel that
because the car's so agile.

I've got lots of managing
settings down here to go from
normal, to sport, to race.

But really when it comes down
to it it's about dropping a
gear and overtaking stuff.
Oh, yes.
It's just awesome.

The motor, it's smooth,
it's responsive.

But most of all, in my head,
it's a D2 Enzo engine for the

same money as a new
911 Porsche.

That has to make it the bargain
of the century,
doesn't it?
[ENGINE REVVING]

So for my money, this is
the best value supercar
on sale right now.

It isn't as pure as
the RS, but it's
something totally different.

And that's what I want from
car ownership, as many

different experiences
as possible.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Sold the Porsche, Bought a Ferrari 599 - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: Aaron Carmody

comments.text:
I wish Ferrari customers were as wowed by quality as they are by "stuff". 
There's an old article floating around about a 550 Maranello that went 
through shocks, a power steering pump, a power steering rack, a compression 
leak, and various suspension bushings and bearings after just a few years 
from new. That to me is completely unacceptable for a car that sold for 
nearly a quarter of a million dollars when new.﻿
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
+djphineart I'm surprised you haven't already. Seems weird to me that 
someone with a garage like yours would care for a second what people had to 
say on youtube. Then again, it's easy to pretend you've got such a garage. 
In that case your responses would make perfect sense...
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
I bow to your superior knowledge, wit and debating skills, I'm off for a 
drive before my cars fall to bits
comments.author: djphineart

comments.text:
+djphineart You're right. I should've gone with the "just another bullshit 
thread" argument. Thank you for your anecdotes as well. Because those can 
never be made up and they always trump testable points.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
Mature, erudite and reasoned argument there sunshine. 

I work in the industry.

I will collect my 8C spider out of storage today which according to you 
will break down tomorrow. 

Go back to your fantasies and unfounded 'facts'. 

You are clearly an angry bitter little man
comments.author: djphineart

comments.text:
+djphineart Let's see. Should I trust people who know what they're talking 
about, who have experience buying and selling these types of cars...or 
should I trust some asshole Ferrari fan boy, who's probably guilty of being 
the typical buyer I described? That's without assuming you're completely 
full of shit, which is very likely. Would someone so adamant and honest 
really care what people say about their precious cars? Probably not. We're 
not even discussing YOUR cars in particular. Here's an idea. Why don't you 
go fuck yourself?
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
+djphineart
 I could just let statistic talk for itself about reliability.
comments.author: jspr2k5

comments.text:
Just another bullshit thread by people who don't even own the cars in 
question. 
All Hearsay and no data.
My F430 cost less to Run than my mates GT3RS. 
I have run a BMW 535D that has been less reliable than both the V12 
Ferraris I Ran. 

Virtually all car makers these days make their cars on flow-lines and 
therefore have mass production quality - yes including Ferrari. I have 
worked directly with a number of the high end car makers and in their 
production systems and can tell you exactly whose cars are reliable and 
whose aren't. I used to race to a national level and I can tell you F-cars 
are not trading on a badge alone. The trouble with the car world is 
reputations take decades to change and some get a free ride even through 
their products are ropey. 

The toyota LFA?
Half a decade behind in tech terms and reliable??!! Good luck with that.

These are the kind of threads you get when people in the Camry market talk 
about things they have no direct experience of.
comments.author: djphineart

comments.text:
+jspr2k5 Depends on what you mean by overpriced. It's like you said. Most 
guys just want the badge. As sports cars, they're very overpriced. The 
quality and the unreliability are undeserving of such a high price tag. 
Thing is, most guys don't keep their cars long enough to care. They just 
like knowing that their cars are "Formula 1 inspired".
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
+Alec D.
 I think it just comes down to them being very much overpriced :-)
comments.author: jspr2k5

comments.text:
+jspr2k5 Certainly. Although these days, you don't have to spend that much 
money for some serious performance. You're right though. The name has a lot 
to do with it. Then again, you can say the same thing about Porsche, but 
their cars are much better built from what I understand. Plus, I refuse to 
believe Ferrari cannot make a long-lasting, reliable sports car. I believe 
they just choose not to.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
+Alec D.
 Hi Alec! I agree that it is unacceptable. Then again you should realize 
that you're not paying 1/4th of a million for a reliable workhorse. But 
you're paying all that money mostly for the name and the performance.
Lexus LFA however won't break down ;)
comments.author: jspr2k5

comments.text:
+djphineart I didn't say their cars were unreliable. I said they were 
trouble for owners because things are constantly breaking. I'm sure they're 
reliable if they're properly maintained (aka all the time). Believe it or 
not, Ferrari doesn't just build cars for you. I rounded off a few examples 
that support my claim, rather than yours. Frankly I trust those people more 
than you anyways.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
Trouble is your hypothesis is simply not supported by then data. Ferrari 
come with a seven year warranty these days. I have had Ferraris from the 
80's 90's 00's and 2010 each one was immeasurably better than the previous. 
It's almost impossible to buy an unreliabile car these days. But I guess 
with a 65mph speed limit and no corners to speak of I could imagine it's 
lack of proper use that has made the stateside cars unreliable.
comments.author: djphineart

comments.text:
+djphineart Well it's not bullshit. Check it out if you're curious. Maybe 
your car is the exception, but I've heard from a few different people that 
they're bad news for owners. I knew a guy who had a California for two 
years. He says it was in the shop all the time. The guys at Classic Car 
Club Manhattan claim that vintage Ferraris are easier to maintain than 
modern ones.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
Modern Ferraris are good quality. I have never had an issue with mine at 
all. I know from experience of others that the biggest issues are with very 
low mileage cars that are just posing pouches. Ferrari tests its cars hard 
as hell and outs millions of miles on em to eliminate faults but some 
owners are just silly doing next to no miles and suffering loads of issues. 
Not sure about the article you read but those days are long gone.
comments.author: djphineart

comments.text: I'm with ya on the experiences but sadly not in that realm of ownership!﻿

The Ferrari team has achieved unparalleled success in Formula One and holds 
many significant records including:

Most Constructors' Championships: 16
Most Drivers' Championships: 15
Most Grands Prix participated (all-time): 890
Most Grands Prix started (all-time): 888[5]
Most wins (all-time): 221[6]
Most podiums (all-time): 679
Most podiums (season): 29
Most one-two finishes (all-time): 81
Most one-two finishes with the same drivers (Michael Schumacher – Rubens 
Barrichello): 24
Most pole positions (all-time): 207
Most WCC points (all-time): 5,834.5
Most WDC points (all-time): 6,736.27
Most fastest laps (all-time): 230
Most consecutive seasons with at least one victory during a season: 20 
(1994–2013)

comments.author: lolzorsPwnage

comments.text: Tell me that heel and toeing isn't better than just flicking a paddle.
comments.author: Sean Bassett

comments.text:
Mostly people who like cars (like me) want the manual because you feel more 
in control and you can rev-match yourself. Heel-toe is just much more fun 
than pulling a paddle. For sure modern dual clutch gearbox is much better 
and it shifts way faster but people want to have a full experience. If you 
are going for full speed on the track then paddles are the only way to go 
but on the road I like manual more. I like rev-matching, using engine 
braking to stop and not even touching the brakes, thinking ahead if I have 
to brake, if I have to go down a gear etc. With paddles changing gear 
becomes easy, simple. It is no longer an occasion. You no longer feel the 
joy of a perfect rev-match or a perfect up shift (which with sporty grabby 
clutches is more difficult than in an ordinary car) because computers nail 
them every single time after you touch a paddle.
comments.author: Martynas Pranckevicius

comments.text:
True, but what they want is just the experience. They want to feel more 
connected to the car, more in control. Not have the car think or drive 
itself, a drivers car. I have many different auto trucks and have driven 
auto cars. For cruisers they are nice, but for fun and experience, I prefer 
the stick.

comments.text:
You are correct in saying that the Porsche is a great everyday supercar... 
What you don't see is that this isn't about having the fastest baddest 
loudest most outrageous car ... it's about being seen in that car... 99%+ 
of the people that buy toys of this caliber drive them to the shoe store , 
the red carpet or the restaurant and never push them at a pace that 
couldn't be bested by a 1986 VW GTI ... If you want the best Porsche buy a 
Boxster S ,, sure there are faster cars but that'll put a smile on your 
face day after day , year after year.

comments.author: Jamie Gavin

comments.text:
In Italy where the car is made it's not seen as such. Typically you'll see 
the older gray haired man cruising through the countryside. Let's not let 
the punks who buy the cars to compensate for any insecurities ruin the 
cars, because it's not the manufacturer's fault and not in their control 
who buys the cars. I'm well travelled and have family in Germany and Italy, 
having spent considerable amounts of time in both countries. You don't see 
many spoiled rich kids in either country driving these cars as commonly as 
it is seen in America. I've been in the US for many years now. To some, the 
ones who are quick to judge and criticize, the young man or any many for 
that matter with a Porsche, Ferrari, Lambo, and the like are seen as rich 
spoiled snobs who are just insecure. Yes there are owners like that but 
that shouldn't ruin the reputation of the respective makers or the drivers 
who legitimately drive the cars for the amazing experience they offer and 
can appreciate them for what they are. As it's said, let's not let a few 
bad apples ruin the whole bunch. In this video Chris is enjoying the car 
the way it should be. He has acknowledged on multiple occasions the car is 
not practical for use in say London for example. But at the end of the day 
it's his money, his preference, and ultimately his choice. He and nobody 
else who makes purchases is not the least bit hurting any one of us. I 
think we have more important matters in society that are worthy of bitching 
about.
